oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How do invasive trees impact shrub layer diversity and productivity in temperate forests?
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dyderski, Marcin K.
Jagodziński, Andrzej M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theme:invasion impact
invasive tree
invasion impact
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Key message</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p><jats:bold>Invasive tree species alter taxonomic diversity and functioning of forest shrub layers:</jats:bold><jats:bold><jats:italic> Prunus serotina</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:bold> increases shrub layer biomass two to three times but decreases its biodiversity,</jats:bold><jats:bold><jats:italic> Robinia pseudoacacia</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:bold> slightly increases shrub layer biomass and has no effect on its biodiversity, while </jats:bold><jats:bold><jats:italic>Quercus rubra</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:bold> both biomass and biodiversity of the shrub layer.</jats:bold></jats:p> </jats:sec><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Context</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p>Although the impact of invasive trees on understory biodiversity is known, very little data exist about their influence on shrub layer biodiversity and productivity.</jats:p> </jats:sec><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Aims</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p>To assess impacts of <jats:italic>Prunus serotina</jats:italic> Ehrh., <jats:italic>Quercus rubra</jats:italic> L., and <jats:italic>Robinia pseudoacacia</jats:italic> L. on shrub layer aboveground biomass, species composition, and alpha diversity.</jats:p> </jats:sec><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Methods</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p>We measured stand structures in a set of 168 study plots established in Wielkopolski National Park (W Poland), and we compared biomass and diversity metrics using generalized mixed-effects linear models.</jats:p> </jats:sec><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Results</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p>We found the lowest aboveground biomass of shrub layers in <jats:italic>Q. rubra</jats:italic> forests. <jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic> forests invaded by <jats:italic>P. serotina</jats:italic> had two to three times higher aboveground biomass than non-invaded forests. <jats:italic>R. pseudoacacia</jats:italic> forests had 27.8% higher shrub layer biomass than <jats:italic>Quercus-Acer-Tilia</jats:italic> forests. We found negative impacts of <jats:italic>Q. rubra</jats:italic> and negligible impacts of <jats:italic>R. pseudoacacia</jats:italic> on shrub layer alpha diversity metrics. However, the effect of <jats:italic>Q. rubra</jats:italic> was similar to native <jats:italic>F. sylvatica</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>P. serotina</jats:italic> negatively affected functional diversity, but its effects were lower in rich <jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic> forests than in poor <jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic> forests.</jats:p> </jats:sec><jats:sec> <jats:title>• <jats:bold><jats:italic>Conclusion</jats:italic></jats:bold> </jats:title> <jats:p>The introduction of alien tree species alters ecosystem services and species diversity of shrub layers. The direction and magnitude of these alterations are alien species-specific and context-dependent. Therefore, their management should account for their impacts.</jats:p> </jats:sec>
